name: sulfate pulp production, from softwood, unbleached | heat, district or industrial, other than natural gas | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/18185/documentation

This dataset represents the European production of unbleached kraft pulp, obtained from softwood for the year 2020. Industry data was used which was provided by the European Pulp Industry Sector Association AISBL (EPIS). The data represents a weighted average of the participating mills located in Europe. The represented technology is considered state of the art for a European average.;PULP is a wood-based raw material to make different paper, board and other products. The pulp, or fibers from the wood are separated in a kraft cooking process in a so-called fiber line. In a recovery line, the chemicals used in the cooking process are recovered to be used again and energy is produced. The third process is effluent treatment where gaseous and liquid discharges to the environment are continuously minimized and monitored.;MAIN END USES FOR MARKET PULP • Tissue (toilet paper) • Graphic papers • Specialty products • Packaging • Fluff pulp • Viscose • CMC etc.;PRODUCTS GENERATED IN THE PULPING PROCESS include crude tall oil, turpentine, electricity, heat etc.;CAPACITIES Global production of unbleached kraft pulp was 36 million tonnes in 2021, of which around 2.3 million was dried, baled and sold to market.;SPECIES Softwood pulp is made from coniferous trees, most typically from different species of pine and spruce. Hardwood pulp is made from non-coniferous trees, in Nordic countries primarily of birch. Eucalyptus hardwood pulp is made exclusively of eucalyptus species.;CHARACTERISTICS Softwood fibers are long and slender and are used to give the paper and board products their strength properties. Hardwood fibers are short and can be rounder and their number per gram of pulp is much larger; they give the end product its smoothness, softness and optical properties like opacity (that you cannot see through the paper).

This activity starts with the transport of woodchips and pulpwood to the pulp factory. Pulpwood and woodchip inputs have activity links to their supplying activities and are therefore not supplied via market datasets

The process includes transports to the pulp mill, wood handling, chemical pulping, and drying process, energy production on-site, recovery cycles of chemicals and internal waste water treatment. The following air emissions were reported in the study: CO2 (fossil and biogenic), SOx (as SO2), TRS (as S), SO2 (reported as S), NOx, Dust (unspecified), and Dust (particle > 2,5 and <10 um). Next to these key emissions, additional emissions from on-site energy production from external and internal fuels were calculated, using emission profiles from ecoinvent combustion processes. Internal biogenic fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Black liquor(2.12E+04MJ/t). Black liquor and tall oil pitch (external fuel) were not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles, e.g. for the black liquor recovery process, were available. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.. The activity ends when the kraft pulp is ready to be sold.
category: C:Manufacturing/17:Manufacture of paper and paper products/170:Manufacture of paper and paper products/1701:Manufacture of pulp, paper and paperboard

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data gathered in 2021 and represents data of 2020 values. Recent technology valid for the upcoming years.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Representing European countries. Data is coming from mills in Europe.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Average European technology in 2020 of kraft pulp production of unbleached pulp
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Industry data provided key emission factors for: CO2 (biogenic), SOx (as SO2), TRS (as S), SO2 (reported as S), NOx, Dust (unspecified), and Dust (particle > 2,5 and <10 um). Additional air emissions resulting from on-site energy production, i.e. the combustion of fuels, were calculated based on industrial heating datasets from the ecoinvent database. The following combustion processes were used: light fuel oil: heat production, light fuel oil, at industrial furnace 1MW, Europe without Switzerland. heavy fuel oil: heat production, heavy fuel oil, at industrial furnace 1MW, Europe without Switzerland.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Weighted average of several mills providing 23% of the European capacity of unbleached kraft pulp from softwood.

exchanges.description: Data provided by industry (EPIS) 2020. Represents steam output sold externally

flow.name: heat, district or industrial, other than natural gas
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/17:Manufacture of paper and paper products/170:Manufacture of paper and paper products/1701:Manufacture of pulp, paper and paperboard

exchanges.description: Estimation based on fuel input data and emission factors from corresponding ecoinvent fuel combustion (see "Extrapolations" comment). Apart from external fuel inputs, internal fuels such as black liquor are generated during the process and supply considerable amounts of process energy. Internal fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Black liquor(2.12E+04MJ/t). Black liquor and tall oil (external fuel) were not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles were available. Emissions from this internal energy generation process are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Represents evaporated water from the combustion process of wood. It is assumed that all hydrogen contained in the wood evaporates as water. The H content of wood is assumed to be 6 %.

exchanges.description: Data provided by industry (EPIS) 2020, indicated in energy content and given as 0.00174 MJ/kg. Calculation into mass/volume was done by using the following conversion factor: Light fuel oil: MJ/kg 42.6 Based on literature, page 18, Report6, part 4. flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/surface water

exchanges.description: This value represents a calculated value, i.e., it is not based on EPIS (2020) data. There was found to be an imbalance in carbon and therefore this value had to be recalculated to close the balance. The original amounts reported by EPIS (2020) are: pine ( 1.632 kg dry/kg)) and spruce (0.454 kg dry/kg))

The original amounts reported by EPIS (2020) are: pine ( 1.632 kg dry/kg)) and spruce (0.454 kg dry/kg))

defaultProvider.category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/02:Forestry and logging/022:Logging/0220:Logging

exchanges.description: Estimation based on fuel input data and emission factors from corresponding ecoinvent fuel combustion (see "Extrapolations" comment). Apart from external fuel inputs, internal fuels such as black liquor are generated during the process and supply considerable amounts of process energy. Internal fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Black liquor(2.12E+04MJ/t). Black liquor and tall oil (external fuel) were not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles were available. Emissions from this internal energy generation process are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.

exchanges.description: Data provided by industry (EPIS) 2020 Represents biofuel from tall oil pitch. Indicated in energy content and given as 0.3787 MJ/kg. Calculated from energetic value with conversion factor 26.48 MJ/kg. The LHV is calculated based on the elemental composition of the substance. Based on the CAS number of the substance (000067-56-1), the chemical formula of the substance is found to be: CH4O, (PubChem 2020). Reference: Kim, S., Chen, J., Cheng, T., Gindulyte, A., He, J., He, S., Li, Q., Shoemaker, B. A., Thiessen, P. A., Yu, B., Zaslavsky, L., Zhang, J., & Bolton, E. E. (2019). PubChem 2019 update: improved access to chemical data. Nucleic acids research, 47(D1), D1102–D1109. https://doi.org/10.1093/nar/gky1033
